page_analysis.text_content:
Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, planters, and other projections

• Fireplaces shall be included in the gross floor area (counted one time) regardless of configuration or design.
• Sheds, planters, and other projections that are higher than 5' count toward gross floor area regardless of configuration or design.

Fig 14 Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, etc.

Chimneys on the upper floors DO NOT COUNT

All configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses COUNT ONCE towards the gross floor area.
Note: Fireplaces not connected to the house are treated like accessory structures, they and count towards FAR if they are greater than 120 sf. They count towards lot coverage always, regardless of size.

Miscellaneous appendages e.g., tool sheds, equipment enclosures, play houses, etc., that are greater than 5' in height, DO COUNT toward gross floor area. (Note: Neither appendages like this nor noise-producing equipment may be located in the required yards).

Note: In 2000, the city of Palo Alto passed an ordinance prohibiting the construction of new wood-burning fireplaces. For details about and possible prohibition, see the chapter 9.06.030

visual_elements.description: A detailed isometric line drawing of a house showing various projections including chimneys, fireplaces, and a shed. Labels indicate that chimneys on upper floors do not count towards gross floor area, while all configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses count once towards gross floor area. A height dimension is shown next to a miscellaneous appendage (tool shed) indicating the 5' height threshold for counting towards gross floor area.

structural_elements.main_heading: Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, planters, and other projections

additional_notes: The page includes a shaded note box on the right side referencing a 2000 Palo Alto ordinance prohibiting new wood-burning fireplaces.
The figure is labeled as Fig 14.
No handwritten annotations or stamps are present.
Page number 19 is at the bottom right corner.
cross_references: Chapter 9.06.030 referenced for details about the Palo Alto ordinance on wood-burning fireplaces.

qualifiers.text: Fireplaces shall be included in the gross floor area (counted one time) regardless of configuration or design.
Sheds, planters, and other projections that are higher than 5' count toward gross floor area regardless of configuration or design.
Fireplaces not connected to the house are treated like accessory structures, they count towards FAR if they are greater than 120 sf. They count towards lot coverage always, regardless of size.
Neither appendages like this nor noise-producing equipment may be located in the required yards.

conditions.text: Fireplaces shall be counted once towards gross floor area.
Projections (sheds, planters, appendages) higher than 5 feet count toward gross floor area.
Fireplaces not connected to the house count towards FAR if greater than 120 square feet.
Fireplaces not connected to the house count towards lot coverage always, regardless of size.

logical_relationships.expression: Projections higher than 5 feet count toward gross floor area AND such appendages or noise-producing equipment may NOT be located in the required yards.

execution_sequence.action: Include fireplaces once in gross floor area calculation regardless of configuration or design.
Count sheds, planters, and other projections higher than 5 feet toward gross floor area, ensuring they are not located in required yards.
For fireplaces not connected to the house, treat as accessory structures and count towards FAR if greater than 120 sf; always count towards lot coverage.
